Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis and Evaluation of Pyrrole-Modified Porphyrins
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports Professor Christian Brueckner of the University of Connecticut, for the synthesis of pyrrole-modified porphyrins from meso-tetraarylporphyrins and the determination of structure/property relationships for this important class of organic molecule. The goal of this work is to establish connections between structural changes in one of the pyrrole sub-units of the porphyrin ring (degree of saturation, steric bulk, and conformational flexibility) and the observed electronic properties in both the ground and electronically excited states (absorption and emission wavelengths, excited state lifetimes). Structurally modified porphyrins find wide applicability in many technical fields, such as therapeutics for disease treatment, chemosensors, and biological imaging agents.

Broader impacts of the research include the multidisciplinary training opportunities for students, from organic synthesis to photochemistry and photophysics. Potential applications for the synthesized molecules include photodynamic therapy agents for cancer treatment, photoacoustic imaging contrast enhancement, and monitoring the aging process in concrete. These applications will be assessed through Professor Brueckner's collaborations with researchers in the biomedical and engineering fields; this includes an international collaboration in the UK. Undergraduate participation in this research will be year-round through an established REU program at the Univeristy of Connecticut, and there is also significant involvement with a local undergraduate institution (Central Connecticut State University).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Algae and higher plants utilize the green magnesium complexes of chlorins (dihydroporphyrins), the chlorophylls, as their key light harvesting pigments. The light is used in photosynthesis, the light-driven generation of carbohydrates. Certain purple bacteria also perform photosynthesis, but they use the purple magnesium complexes of  bacteriochlorins (tetrahydroporphyrins), the bacteriochlorophylls. The light-harvesting functions made the study of chlorins and bacteriochlorins most attractive to chemists aiming at the understanding of the function of the photosynthetic apparatus and the realization of artificial light-harvesting systems. Furthermore, several other technical and biomedical applications were found for these molecules.

Chlorins and bacteriochlorins absorb light within the so-called ‘spectroscopic window of tissue’. This window describes the red wavelengths that penetrate tissue the deepest. This is the ultimate reason why meats look red – all wavelength get absorbed (by the red blood pigments), except the red wavelengths are allowed through. This is important because many chlorins possess very attractive physical properties that suggest their utilization as photochemotherapeutics, imaging agents, or optical labels. Photochemotherapeutics use a combination of a chlorin and light to cause a therapeutic effect, such as the removal of unwanted (cancerous) tissue; imaging agents use the chlorins to make fine blood vessels, for example, better visible to diagnose any disease or the location of abnormal tissue; optical labels are used to tag certain molecular disease markers, allowing their detection at very low levels.

Despite their ubiquity, however, naturally occurring chlorophylls are not suitable for many of these applications as there are chemically fairly unstable – after all, a green leaf also turns yellow, red, or brown as soon as the plant’s machinery to keep the chlorophyll stable is switched off by a cold snap or drought. Chlorophylls and bacteriochlorophylls are also hard to modify to optimize their performance. Therefore, a diverse range of methods toward synthetic chlorins were developed: One approach, for example, is the step-by-step building of the chlorin or bacteriochlorin. Another approach is the conversion of a larger compound to a chlorin or bacteriochlorin – think of either building a convertible from parts or by chopping off the roof of a sedan. Here, the sedan that can be chopped to chlorins and bacteriochlorins are the so-called porphyrins (that are, incidentally, at the origin of the red color of blood and tissue as the red blood pigment hemoglobin contains a porphyrin iron complex).

NSF funding allowed us to continue the development of a synthetic methodology that takes a readily available synthetic porphyrins and ‘chops it’ to make a chlorin and bacteriochlorin. We coined our approach the ‘breaking and mending of porphyrins strategy’. True chlorins and bacteriochlorins are composed of four pyrrole building blocks. But as our strategy changes in the ‘chopping’ process one or two pyrroles into non-pyrrole building blocks, we generate not true chlorins and bacteriochlorins but chlorin and bacteriochlorin analogues, respectively. They ‘look and feel’ like real chlorins and bacteriochlorins.

Mainly driven by a small group of PhD students, this strategy produced numerous classes of colorful compounds, many of which were shown to possess the desirable photophysical properties required for their applications, combined with high chemical stability and accessibility.
